item.title: Here is a full explanation of everything you need to know about how to ride a motorcycle as a beginner. In my head, this only took about three or four minutes, but clearly I was wrong. #Motorcycle #HowToRideAMotorcycle #Moto #BeginnerMotorcycleRider #Rebe

item.title: Just installed a new exhaust on my Honda Rebel 1100. The mic doesn’t do it justice, but trust me—it sounds fantastic. Deep tone, better flow, and a whole new vibe on the throttle. Let me know what you think. #motorcycle #HondaRebel1100 #ExhaustUpgrade #Bi
item.description: Just installed a new exhaust on my Honda Rebel 1100. The mic doesn’t do it justice, but trust me—it sounds fantastic. Deep tone, better flow, and a whole new vibe on the throttle. Let me know what you think. #motorcycle #HondaRebel1100 #ExhaustUpgrade #Bi

item.title: How to Get Gas on a Motorcycle Step 1: Roll up like a boss. Step 2: Turn off the bike before you gas up (trust me). Step 3: Pop the tank, yes, with the key, because we’re still living that analog life. Step 4: Don’t shove the nozzle in like it owes you mo
item.description: How to Get Gas on a Motorcycle Step 1: Roll up like a boss. Step 2: Turn off the bike before you gas up (trust me). Step 3: Pop the tank, yes, with the key, because we’re still living that analog life. Step 4: Don’t shove the nozzle in like it owes you mo
item.author: cliffy_jr

item.title: Making a Left Turn and Merging Onto the Freeway When you’re turning left to merge onto the freeway, make sure you rev out your gears. Don’t short-shift or baby the throttle. You need power, not hesitation. Revving out gives you more control over the engin
item.description: Making a Left Turn and Merging Onto the Freeway When you’re turning left to merge onto the freeway, make sure you rev out your gears. Don’t short-shift or baby the throttle. You need power, not hesitation. Revving out gives you more control over the engin
item.author: cliffy_jr

item.title: Let’s Practice Making a U-Turn Take your time. This isn’t about speed, it’s about control. There’s no shame in living in the friction zone and rolling on throttle as needed. That balance between clutch and throttle is what makes the turn smooth. You don’t
item.description: Let’s Practice Making a U-Turn Take your time. This isn’t about speed, it’s about control. There’s no shame in living in the friction zone and rolling on throttle as needed. That balance between clutch and throttle is what makes the turn smooth. You don’t

item.title: The pants aren’t as tight as they look I promise. But here’s how to make a right turn on a motorcycle at a stoplight. Wright turns don’t have to be scared. They’re just short left. Turns going the other way.
item.description: The pants aren’t as tight as they look I promise. But here’s how to make a right turn on a motorcycle at a stoplight. Wright turns don’t have to be scared. They’re just short left. Turns going the other way.
item.author: cliffy_jr

item.title: 1000cc Motorcycles Are Easier Than You Think Big bikes get a bad rep, but here’s the truth: 1000cc bikes are some of the easiest to ride. Why? Because 1st and 2nd gear cover almost everything you need in city traffic and slow-speed situations. Tons of tor

item.title: Getting Your Motorcycle License and Taking the MSF Course If you’re thinking about riding, start with the Motorcycle Safety Foundation (MSF) course. It’s one of the best ways to build confidence, learn real-world skills, and earn your license in most stat

item.title: Lane Filtering and Freeway Merging Tips Lane Filtering: • Only filter when it’s legal and safe • Watch mirrors and front wheels—they move before the car does • Keep your speed difference low—5 to 15 mph faster than traffic • Don’t force gaps that aren

item.title: Having multiple bikes is awesome… But choosing which one to ride? That’s a problem I didn’t see coming—yet I fully welcome it. Each bike has its own personality, its own mood, its own kind of fun. Some days I want smooth and chill. Other days? I want loud
item.description: Having multiple bikes is awesome… But choosing which one to ride? That’s a problem I didn’t see coming—yet I fully welcome it. Each bike has its own personality, its own mood, its own kind of fun. Some days I want smooth and chill. Other days? I want loud
item.author: cliffy_jr

item.title: Lane Splitting Tip: Keep your speed no more than 10 to 15 mph faster than traffic. Going double the speed is asking for trouble. It cuts your reaction time and puts you in danger when cars make sudden moves. Stay smooth, stay predictable, and ride like ev
item.description: Lane Splitting Tip: Keep your speed no more than 10 to 15 mph faster than traffic. Going double the speed is asking for trouble. It cuts your reaction time and puts you in danger when cars make sudden moves. Stay smooth, stay predictable, and ride like ev
item.author: cliffy_jr
